Given these findings, particularly the extensive lymph node involvement (11 out of 17 nodes) and the perforation of the visceral peritoneum, the prognosis is poor. The high stage of cancer (pT4aN2b) and the presence of lymphovascular invasion further suggest a high risk of recurrence and metastasis, which significantly reduces the likelihood of survival after 2.2 years.
